notesStmt.note: A satire arising from a bill debated in the Massachusetts General Court for laying an excise on wine and spirituous liquors retailed and consumed within the province. It was ordered by the General Court to be burnt by the common hangman.

"Samuel Waterhouse is supposed to be the author, as it is known he made use of the same pseudonym in 1760. It has also been attributed to Benjamin Church (1734-1778). In the copy in the possession of the Boston Athenaeum is written in contemporary handwriting: The supposed authors Benj. Brandon & Rev.d Dr. [Jonathan] Mayhew."--Evans. The attribution to Church is rejected in Sibley's Harvard graduates.
Printed by Zechariah Fowle. Fowle's brother Daniel was arrested on suspicion of involvement in the publication of the work. Cf. Thomas, Isaiah. The history of printing in America, 1970, p. 126-132.

div.p: THE MONSTER of MONSTERS: A true and faithful NARRATIVE of a mo≈øt remarkable Phaenomenon lately ≈øeen in the METROPOLIS; to the great Surprize and Terror of His MAJESTY's good Subjects: Humbly DEDICATED to all the Virtuo≈øi of New-England.
By Thomas Thumb, E≈øq.

lg.l: Fierce as ten Furies, terrible as Hell!
Whence, and what are thou, execrable Shape!
That dar'≈øt, the grim and terrible, advance
Thy mi≈øcreated Front athwart my Way!

div.p: Printed in July 1754.

div.head: THE MONSTER OF MONSTERS.
div.p: IT is hoped that the common idle Stories about Mon≈øters and Prodigies, which amu≈øe and plea≈øe the Vulgar, while they di≈øgu≈øt ≈øober and rea≈øonable Men, will be no in≈øuperable Objection again≈øt the en≈øuing Narrative: Tho' the Author is aware, that the Frequency of ≈øuch Tales, which are ≈øoon found to be de≈øtitute of all Truth and Reality, will be a con≈øiderable Prejudice to it. But let its Reception be what it will, he thinks the Subject of it too ≈øingular and remarkable, to have no publick Notice taken of it. And in full Confidence, that the Truth will, at length, ≈øurmount all Ob≈øtacles, and triumph over the mo≈øt determin'd Infidelity, he can chearfully ri≈øque all the Credit he has in the World, whether more or le≈øs, upon the Verity of what follows.

THERE lately appeared, in this Metropolis, a MONSTER of the mo≈øt hideous Form, and terrible A≈øpect; ≈øuch an one as was never before ≈øeen in America by any Man's Eyes; and, I believe, no where el≈øe; to be ≈øure not in the Briti≈øh Dominions. There was indeed one
formerly a little like him in Turkey: another in Italy; and, as ≈øome ≈øay, there is one in France at this Day. He had more Heads and Horns than any Bea≈øt de≈øcribed in the Apocalyp≈øe; and pu≈øhed more furiou≈øly than the He-Goat in Daniel. His Teeth re≈øembled tho≈øe of an overgrown Lion: His Trunk was like that of an Elephant; the Protuberance on his Back, like that of a Camel; his Eye (for he had only one with all his Heads) was like that of Polyphemus; his Ears were of a much greater Longitude than tho≈øe of good St. Francis's traying Auditory: The Wings which came out of his Sides, were like tho≈øe of an Eagle: his Hair (or rather Feathers) was like Nebuchadnezzar's, after he was driven from among Men; his Claws, like tho≈øe of a Bear, only much bigger; and for a Tail, Gulliver's Monkey was a Fool to him.

FROM what Parts he was brought, I do not certainly know; and would not deceive the Reader by pretending to an Acquaintance with ≈øuch Circum≈øtances as I am ignorant of. Some a≈ø≈øert that he came from the South; others, from the We≈øt; and ≈øome, from the Ea≈øt: But I rather think (if he were not brought forth among≈øt us) that he came out of the North; con≈øidering the Evils and the De≈øtruction which his Appearance portended.

HE was fir≈øt ≈øeen here in a large A≈ø≈øembly of Matrons; who, one would have thought, from their natural Timidity, mu≈øt have been univer≈øally ≈øhocked at ≈øo tremendous a Sight. But (wonderful to relate!) they were, almo≈øt to a Woman, greatly plea≈øed with the Creature: And though many of them were not pa≈øt the Age of Pregnancy; yet I have not heard of a ≈øingle one that mi≈øcarried; nor indeed of more than about half a Score that were even thrown into Hy≈øterick Fits. The far greater Part were ≈øo ≈øtrangely captivated with this Mon≈øter, that they fondled and play'd with him: and would even have
taken him into their Laps and Bo≈øoms, had he not been of too unweildy a Size. "What a pretty Lap-Dog, ≈øaid one and another, would this Creature make, if he was not of ≈øuch an enormous Bulk!" And a third even call'd him Sh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ k, as ≈øhe lean'd again≈øt his Probo≈øcis.

THOSE few Ladies of better Ta≈øte, who ≈øpake of him as an ugly, deformed, over grown Bea≈øt of Prey; and would have had him immediately turn'd out of the Hou≈øe, were cried out upon as having no Ta≈øte at all; and even threatned, that they ≈øhould never come there again, to drink Tea and Coffee in ≈øuch polite Company. It is thought that two Attornies Wives, be≈øides ≈øeveral other Ladies of le≈øs Di≈øtinction, would have admitted him, had he been of an amorous Turn, like Fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s and the Satyrs, to ≈øome Familiarities not ≈øo fit to be mention'd. Europa was never more enamour'd of a Bull; nor Leda, of a Swan: and both of them had certainly a far ju≈øter Ta≈øte than the≈øe modern Ladies. He was even voted, in Form, by them, who ought to be the be≈øt Judges of Beauty, to be the prettie≈øt, hand≈øome≈øt Creature, they had ever laid their Eyes upon, in all their Lives.

THIS A≈ø≈øembly of Matrons, not content with admiring the Mon≈øter them≈øelves, took great Pains, both by Care≈ø≈øes, and Threats, to gain others over to their odd Opinion. They decorated him with Ribbands and Garlands, like an ancient Victim, or rather like an Egyptian God, by the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of a Prie≈øte≈øs to be mention'd hereafter: and having fir≈øt done Homage to him them≈øelves on bended Knees; ≈øent him in that Dre≈øs, to another Company of Ladies, who u≈øed to meet to dance, and to regale them≈øelves, at no great Di≈øtance from their own A≈ø≈øembly-Room.

THOSE of the Club, who were ordered to e≈øcort him thither, came and ≈øaid; "Behold here, Ladies, one of
the mo≈øt lovely, charming, adorable Creatures, that ever your Eyes were laid upon! Pray, good Ladies, join with us in our Admiration, and ≈øhare our Plea≈øure. O! the Beauty of the dear Creature! See how he looks! View him all over critically and exactly! Who ever ≈øaw the like!‚ÄîFor the Entertainment and Delight of the Publick, (and in order to put Money into our own Coffers, to game with &c. when our Hu≈øbands are out of Humour) we have re≈øolv'd to hire a great Number of Per≈øons to carry him thro' the Country for a Sight. So good a Show will certainly give infinite Plea≈øure to People of every Rank; at the ≈øame Time that it will bring in Ca≈øh enough to find us all, in Tea, and Coffee, in Equipages and fine Clothes, in Citron Water and gaming Money, as long as we live. Come, dear Ladies, ca≈øt in your Lot among us, and let us go Snacks! We ≈øhall all find our Profit in it; and others, their Plea≈øure and Amu≈øement."

MANY of this latter A≈ø≈øembly were as marvellou≈øly plea≈øed with the Mon≈øter, as tho≈øe of the former; and ≈øoon expre≈ø≈øed their Readine≈øs to concur the Motion, for carrying him about for a Show. But a middle-aged Gentlewoman of a more refined Ta≈øte, and who was both in Stature and Judgment, Superiour to mo≈øt, even of the other Sex, ≈øtood up; and ≈øpake to this Purpo≈øe. "What Demon has gotten Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of you, my dear Ladies! and deprives you of your Sen≈øes to ≈øuch a Degree, as to make you take this filthy Mon≈øter for a Beauty! I am afraid to come near him, lea≈øt he ≈øhould hook up my Petticoats, and rip up my Stays, if nothing wor≈øe! And how he whi≈øks his na≈øty Tail in your Faces, at many Yards di≈øtance! Mercy on us! This a Beauty! Look on tho≈øe Ears! See that plaguy hump Back! View that bloody, ferocious Eye; if you can look ≈øteadily upon it! See tho≈øe diabolical Horns! Look on that triple Row of Ivory, in each of his enormous Jaws! And how he "Grins horribly, a gha≈øtly Smile!" Ob≈øerve
his Feet, how they are Cloven; branching out into five or ≈øix Claws, of huge Length and Thickne≈øs! A pretty Creature, upon my Con≈øcience, for Women to be taken with! How much better you like Horns, than your Spou≈øes do? This a Creature, to be carried about the Country for an agreable Spectacle! And becau≈øe you are run mad, for≈øooth! we mu≈øt run mad to keep you Company; or el≈øe fall under your Di≈øplea≈øure! No truly! I like not your fancy; nor this ≈øtrange Propo≈øal! If you ≈øhould ≈øend this more than Cerberian-mouth'd Mon≈øter through all the Towns in the Province, take my Word for it, you would rather fright the Inhabitants out of them, than draw Spectators about him. And tho' you expect to get ≈øo much Money by this Show, I am much mi≈øtaken if you would get enough to defray the Charges of carting it about. People will rather conclude you ≈øend a Mon≈øter to devour and de≈øtroy, than a Spectacle to entertain and delight, them! Fye upon it, Ladies! What evil Spirit put this Notion into your Heads; and deludes you at ≈øuch a Rate! To be plain with you, you had far better hire a Score or two of the ≈øturdie≈øt Butchers in the Town, to kill this horrible Creature out-right, before he does any Mi≈øchief; and to throw him, Piece-meal, into the Dock, than run the Ri≈øque of keeping him alive a ≈øingle Day. What would become of us all, if he ≈øhould break his Chain, get out of his Cage, and range about at large, ≈øeeking whom to devour! Doors and Locks, and Bolts, and Bars, would be no Security again≈øt him. He (having a Faculty of contracting and enlarging him≈øelf at Plea≈øure) would ea≈øily climb into our Bed Chambers; and tho' we ≈øhould hide our≈øeves down in our Wine Cellars among the Ca≈øks; he would find us out even there; drag us into Day Light, and gorge him≈øelf with our mangled Carca≈øes! A pretty Creature to be kept for a Show, truly! Thus ≈øpake Mrs. GRACCHA; for that was the Name of this accompli≈øh'd Lady.

THIS Speech was ≈øoon ≈øeconded and thirded by other Ladies of great Merit Madam CORNELIA in particular, (an open, plain-hearted Lady; and in high E≈øteem, tho' low of Stature) among≈øt other Things very pertinent to the Occa≈øion ≈øaid; "Well! I am equally ≈øurprized, Ladies, at your Ta≈øte and at your Judgement. I wonder you can imagine that ≈øuch a Spectacle as you propo≈øe, can be reli≈øhed by the People of this Country; or that any good can come of this Project. Are you really in earne≈øt, Ladies! Why! Do you not remember, when a Leopard only was carried about for a Show, a few Years ≈øince, what Confu≈øion and Terror People were thrown into! Not only tho≈øe of our own Sex; but the Men al≈øo; even ≈øome of the Military Order! Was not the Con≈øternation ≈øtill greater, and more univer≈øal, when the Lion was carted about, ≈øome Time before? What terrible Apprehen≈øions had People of his breaking from his Durance, and eating them half up! And more lately, when there was only a Wild-Cat of uncommon Size and fiercene≈øs, and longer Fangs than u≈øual, carried from Place to Place; you have not, ≈øurely, forgot how precipitately even ≈øuch brave, valiant Men as C‚Äîpt‚Äîins and C‚Äîll‚Äîn‚Äîls fled before it; leaving the Towns where they re≈øpectively lived, upon the fir≈øt News of its approach! The Courage of ≈øuch Gentlemen, was never doubted by any one; And it is certain they would have ≈øingly encountered the whole Rebel Army in Scotland, with the Pretender at its Head! But the People of this Country, I ≈øay, cannot endure wild Bea≈øts, and Lawle≈øs Devourers! How then, Ladies, in the Name of Amazement, can it enter into your Thoughts, that they will be delighted with a Mon≈øter! e≈øpecially ≈øuch an huge, dreadful one as this; which might devour half a Country Village for a Breakfa≈øt; and be hungry ≈øtill! Will they give their Money freely, do you think, for ≈øuch a Show! When you reflect, Ladies, upon the Abborrence and Dread which they have of all wild Creatures; of all Bea≈øts of Prey; when you con≈øi≈øter how contrary ≈øuch
Shews are to their natural Ta≈øte, Genius and Manners; when you con≈øider farther, what Mi≈øchiefs may be actually done by this dreadful Creature; I ≈øhall think you ought to drink no Tea, except ≈øuch as is made of Hellebore, if you per≈øi≈øt in the project of carrying about this Creature; a Mon≈øter, as much more formidable than a Lion, as a Lion, than a common Puppy-Dog!"

THESE two Speeches, together with ≈øome others, were very attentively heard by the Club: And, in ≈øhort, made ≈øo good an Impre≈ø≈øion, that the major Part adopted the Sentiments of them; and rejected the Motion of the other Club, after due Deliberation. Whereupon tho≈øe who pre≈øented the Mon≈øter to them for their Approbation, returned with him to their own Si≈øterhood, in great Wrath and Indignation for this imaginary Affront; and endeavoured, Thale≈øtris-like, to inflame the Pa≈ø≈øions of the A≈ø≈øembly; which they found no very hard Ta≈øk to perform. The greater Part being now well heated with Anger; ≈øome with laced Tea, others with Gin, and ≈øome with Citron Water; they came to a Re≈øolution to ≈øend the Mon≈øter immediately back again, with another Me≈ø≈øage; giving out their Menaces, concerning what they would do to any Lady of the other Si≈øterhood, who ≈øhould be ≈øo hardy as to reject their Propo≈øal a ≈øecond Time. "My Word for it, ≈øays one, that Lady that ≈øhall dare to open her Lips in di≈øparagement of this rare, curious, lovely Animal, ≈øhall have her Pinners torn off her Head; and her Sack ≈øtripped over her Ears!" "And my Word for it, ≈øays another, although they pretend to be at lea≈øt our Equals, if not our Superiours; and to have as good a Right as we, to enjoy their own Opinion about the Beauty and Deformity of any Creature living; yet we will make them know the Difference, I warrant you! We are the mo≈øt numerous Club; and will ≈øoon cau≈øe them to ≈øubmit to our Determination; or pull all their Caps and Ruffles off! Do they call this, a Mon≈øter? a dangerous Mon≈øter,
nor fit to be kept alive! I ≈øay again, we will have him carried about for a Show, let them ≈øay what they will: And they ≈øhall join with us too in this Project, or we'll know why; and that's more!"

THE Mon≈øter's greate≈øt Admirers in this A≈ø≈øembly, were (1) Madam RIXA; formerly a lean, poor Gentlewoman, thought to be in a Con≈øumption; and who u≈øed to go very meanly clad: But of late Years, plumped up to a con≈øiderable Magnitude; and become a perfect Belle, with her rich Lace and Ruffles; and almo≈øt every Female Ornament, excepting that of a meek and quiet Heart. Some idle People in≈øinuate, that ≈øhe got her Money by Gaming; and that ≈øhe never u≈øed to play fairly: but I do not concern my≈øelf about ≈øuch Matters.

(2) MADAM PROTEA; a Gentlewoman that was lately ≈øeen in Publick with a remarkable Head Dre≈øs. This Lady has many good Qualities: but is very variable and incon≈øtant in every Thing; ≈øo that it was expected her Pa≈ø≈øion for the Mon≈øter, would have been but ≈øhort-lived. However, to the Surprize of every one, She, who never u≈øed to be of the ≈øame Mind two Days together, has, in this Re≈øpect, ≈øhown all the Steadine≈øs and Per≈øeverance of a Saint; continues to extol the Beauty of the Mon≈øter, and ≈øeems determin'd to live and dye in the Faith of his Charms.

(3) ANOTHER of his great Admirers was Madam RUTI ‚Ä¢ A, the Wife of a very fine, hand≈øome Gentleman: to find whom making Panegyricks, with ≈øo much Zeal upon ≈øuch an ugly Creature, was a Surprize to all: e≈øpecially when this Zeal carried her to ≈øpeak even of her own aged Mother, with le≈øs Decorum and Re≈øpect than became her. For the good old Lady happening to be her Tenant, ≈øhe threatned that ≈øhe would turn her out, if ≈øhe did not approve her Pa≈ø≈øion. The Gentlewoman of
whom I am now ≈øpeaking, is ≈øingularly plain and mode≈øt in her Dre≈øs; commonly appearing abroad in a dark Ru≈ø≈øel Gown. She is a Lady of real and great Worth; but ought certainly to have been a better Judge of Propriety and Decency, as well as of Beauty and Deformity, than to have ≈øpake and acted in the Manner ≈øhe did.

(4) Mrs. AQUATICA (a jolly-looking, pur≈øy Gentlewoman; and a little a≈øthmatical) was al≈øo a great Admirer of the Mon≈øter; nur≈øing it with much Tenderne≈øs, and a peculiar Fondne≈øs. Nor is this ≈øtrange, if, as ≈øome have hinted, ≈øhe was the real Mother of it; though by Means of an unlawful Commerce. But whether this be Fact, or not; and if it is, whether the Mon≈øter i≈ø≈øued from her Head, as Pallas did from the Thunderer's, according to the Pagan Mythology, or whether it dropped from her Belly, as the unformed Cub falls from the prowling, ravenous Bear's; I confe≈øs my≈øelf unable to determine. Nor is it very material, ≈øuppo≈øing it to be her Offspring, whether the Foetus was originally conceived in her Brain, or Belly; ≈øince a le≈øs mon≈øtrous Production could not have been rationally expected from either; nor a more perfect from the one than from the other. This Matron was the Wife of a certain great Farmer living out of the Town; who had many Tenants under him; and it is ≈øaid, he was wont to treat them with ≈øuch Severity, Haughtine≈øs and In≈øolence, e≈øpecially in gathering in his Rents, that he has often been in Jeopardy of a broken Pate. But it is not the Hu≈øband, but the Wife, gentle Reader, that we have now to do with. She, as was hinted before, was at lea≈øt the Nur≈øe, if not the Mother of the Mon≈øter. And though ≈øhe has ≈øo liberally given Food and Nutriment to it, yet ≈øhe expects, in her Turn, to receive Nouri≈øhment from it. For although I ≈øometimes ≈øpeak of this Creature, as being of the Male Gender, I would now acquaint the Reader, that it is really an Hermaphrodite; and has a Multitude of large Teats;
at which many hope to hang in Rows, like ≈øo many ≈øucking Pigs, or rather like Imps at the Teats of Witches. Nor need I ob≈øerve here, what every one knows already, That though Mon≈øters are ≈øaid not to breed; yet they frequently give Milk in prodigious Quantities. But then it takes the Produce of a whole Country to feed one. And indeed, if this ≈øhould live, I fear we ≈øhall find the old Proverb concerning the Sterility of Mon≈øters, erroneous.

(5) ANOTHER of the≈øe Mon≈øter-loving-Matrons, was Madam CAPILLA; a very ≈øleek, ≈øoft-≈øpoken, double-tongu'd, ro≈øey Gentlewoman; though, I think, ≈øomewhat older than either of the other. She was formerly the Wife of a Prie≈øt of Ap ‚Ä¢ s in Egypt, and her≈øelf a Prie≈øte≈øs. For which Rea≈øon, as ≈øome ≈øay, ≈øhe was employed to u≈øher this Mon≈øter into the World, with all the Pomp and Ceremonial, practis'd by the Pagan Hierarchy: Tho' ≈øhe had not, for many Years pa≈øt, concerned her≈øelf much about Religion in any Shape; but given her≈øelf up to Matters meerly worldly and ≈øecular, at the be≈øt. However, ≈øince the Sacerdotal Character is indelible, (although the Office is pro≈øtituted ever ≈øo much, or even wholly renounced) a more proper Per≈øon, certainly, could not have been pitched upon to perform the ≈øaid Rites, con≈øidering for what Creature they were to be performed!

(6) A younger Lady than either of the former, was a con≈øiderable Admirer of, and a warm Advocate for, the Mon≈øter. She is remarkable for a Chin, ≈øomewhat immoderate in Length; and wears both Night and Day a very large Beauty Spot upon her right Cheek: In which there is this farther ob≈øervable, that it is very difficult to take it off, without taking the Skin away with it! This Lady was very lately in high E≈øteem in the Town: And although her Conduct with Relation to the Mon≈øter, has been exceptionable; yet it is not doubted but that Time,
and a circum≈øpect Behaviour, will re≈øtore a Lady of ≈øo many laudable Qualities, to her former Reputation.

(7.) Mrs. BIDDY brings up the Rear of all the≈øe Ladies; and Claims a very particular Notice. She is the Wife of a certain valiant C‚Äîll‚Äîn‚Äîl; and, in Imitation of him, wears a great Tuft of Feathers on the top of her Head; ≈øo weighty, that it is thought to have over≈øtrain'd, and weaken'd, that tender Part; and made her a little giddy. She pretends to a great deal of Religion; tho' but few think ≈øhe has more Virtue than her Neighbours. She has the Misfortune to have a very ≈øly, cunning, Jewi≈øh Look; and not being of the faire≈øt Complexion, nor able to look a good Chri≈øtian in the Face; ≈øome have ≈øu≈øpected her to be of that Religion; and hinted, that the only Rea≈øon why ≈øhe is not conformed to 'its whole Ritual, is her Sex. THEY accordingly laid the Ca≈øe before him, in Pre≈øence of the Mon≈øter; with many Encomiums on his Beauty, &c. "Ladies, ≈øaid he, I am extremely obliged to you for the Compliment you are plea≈øed to pay to my Ta≈øte and Judgment; tho' I am not le≈øs a≈øtoni≈øhed at your own. THUS ≈øpake the Friend of the Ladies, the Friend of all. HAVING thus fini≈øhed my true and faithful Narrative of the mo≈øt formidable Mon≈øter, that was ever ≈øeen in this Land; I now beg leave to Congratulate my dear Countrymen, that we are not without an HERCULES! YOU will at once conclude, that this Dog of H‚Äîll, ought not only to have his enormous Length of Ears and Tail dimini≈øhed; his Teeth pulled out, and his Claws paired, but that his very Head (or Heads rather; for they are many!) ought to be excis'd; I mean cut off. It is to be hoped that what has been ≈øaid will have no Tendency to excite any undue Re≈øentment again≈øt the Ladies I have had Occa≈øion to ≈øpeak of in this Narrative. div.p: THE Author of the preceeding Narrative, having hitherto been ≈øpeaking in Je≈øt, thinks its now Time to ≈øpeak in Earne≈øt. WHAT happen'd at the Printing-Hou≈øe about an Hour ago, determin'd me to take this Cour≈øe. The Printer a≈ø≈øur'd me, he had found out my whole Meaning, as plainly as if I had told him my ≈øelf. ANOTHER of the Workmen gave it as his ≈øolid Opinion, that it was de≈øign'd as a Satyre upon the Women. For Women, ≈øaid he, are ≈øet in a ridiculous Light, from the Beginning

AS my Back was turn'd, I overheard an unlucky Jackanaps of a Boy, that ≈øtood by, talking to his Fellow-Prentice: Witches for a Gue≈øs! ≈øaid he: and Ma≈øter always was! AS I was going home, tho't I, if People go on gue≈ø≈øing and gue≈ø≈øing, applying and applying, at this Rate; and making Sen≈øes, where there was none before; what may they not come to at la≈øt! NOW to prevent every Thing of this Sort, I think my ≈øelf bound in Duty to declare, that my Narrative (like mo≈øt Travellers Stories) has not one Word of Truth in it. There has not, to my Knowledge, been any Mon≈øter in the Town; nor any Thing like a Mon≈øter. There has nothing happened lately which could naturally give Occa≈øion to ≈øuch a Fiction; nor any Thing to which it can be ju≈øtly apply'd, in the Way of Allegorical Interpretation. And the Per≈øons who ≈øhall attempt this, mu≈øt be very ≈øimple, or ill-natur'd; for it is merely a Work of Fancy and Imagination; of which there is neither Type nor Antitype. And having declar'd this, I think I may innocently let it ≈øee the Light, as a very harmle≈øs, toothle≈øs Production; wi≈øhing that all other Romancers and Story Tellers
had been as fair and ingenuous, to undeceive their Readers, as ≈øoon as they had fini≈øh'd their Lies!

BUT if I mu≈øt open my whole Heart, as to my Views in writing this, (which I have not yet done) I ≈øhall certainly appear a little vain. To tell the Truth, I have long de≈øign'd to write the KNAVE's PROGRESS, in Imitation of the PILGRIM's, by the excellent Mr. John Bunyan; And I tho't, that by exerci≈øing my ≈øelf a little in this fanciful, my≈øtical Way of writing, I might execute that great Work the better when I ≈øet my ≈øelf about it. And you mu≈øt excu≈øe my Vanity, gentle Reader, if I tell you, that I am not without ≈øome Hopes of performing the Task in ≈øuch a Manner, as may render me not wholly unde≈øerving the Title of his Succe≈ø≈øor If this little Attempt in the Romantick Way, meets with due Encouragement from the Publick; I propo≈øe to ≈øet about that large, voluminous Work alluded to, as ≈øoon as Lei≈øure will permit.. Homer wrote of Frogs, (an ugly Sort of Creature) before he wrote of Kings and the Trojan War. Even Gnats employ'd the Pen of Maro, before it immortaliz'd Mezentius and other Heroes.
